awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund the 7th annual MINDS (Mentoring for Innovative Design Solutions) Workshop organized by Alpha Eta Mu Beta National Biomedical Engineering Honors Society. The workshop will be held virtually from October 6-9 in parallel with the BMES 2021 Annual Meeting. This will allow the students selected for the MINDS Scholar Program to also participate in the BMES Annual Meeting. The MINDS Scholar Program is an innovative approach that provides students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period while building necessary engineering design skills including three key considerations that are not usually stressed in coursework projects. The three key considerations are (1) market considerations for commercialization (unmet need, size of market reimbursement potential, etc.), (2) regulatory strategy, and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection. The 7th MINDS Scholar Program will focus on the development of biomedical technologies that solve health care problems while considering end-user needs such as people with disabilities. The program begins with an initial workshop where students will virtually meet their team members, drawn from other universities across the US, and mentors. The team then selects a central design idea that will be developed over the subsequent 5 months. Students will then work with their teams and mentors to develop a design solution that considers issues such as market evaluation, intellectual property issues, and regulation. Teams will be encouraged to submit their designs to various design contests, investment opportunities, and grant programs. The collaborative and long-distance communication skills that the team will develop will better equip them to work in an environment that is increasingly dependent on communication between distant facilities and customers.

The majority of design courses in the US, particularly in biomedical engineering programs, do not have sufficient time to provide students with a strong experience in the non-technical aspects that are key to design success: market potential, intellectual property, and regulation. This program will provide students, selected through a competitive process from across the US, with key experience related to real-world design processes for medical systems. It will also provide students with significant experience in working on a geographically separated team and with peers from varied backgrounds, both of which are strongly valued by industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Alpha Eta Mu Beta (AHMB) is the international biomedical engineering honor society, which recognizes and encourages excellence in the field of Biomedical Engineering and Bioengineering. AHMB's "Mentoring for INnovative Design Solutions" (MINDS) Scholar Program provides biomedical engineering students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 6-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills not sufficiently emphasized in regular coursework. For instance, (1) market considerations for commercialization (why is this product needed, what market is there for it and how big is this market, etc.), (2) regulatory strategy (what regulations does the product need to meet, and what would be a successful strategy to get the product approved), and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection (how can the design team protect others from using their idea or copying their product).

 

In order for biomedical engineers to address public healthcare needs, they need to have the knowledge and skills to navigate every step and aspect of bringing a product to market. During the program, MINDS Scholars enhance their knowledge of product design, but they also learn how to effectively communicate with collaborators from other schools and organizations using online tools, which are becoming an increasingly important skill in today's work environment.

 

Participation in MINDS is through a competitive application process among biomedical engineering majors. Each annual MINDS Scholar Program starts with a workshop, where students meet their team members and mentors, and create an action plan. They select a central design idea that is refined during the 6-month period, and they actively collaborate to advance the project forward, culminating in a final report.

 

In 2021-2022, 24 students (5 teams) completed the program with guidance from 10 mentors. Due to Covid-19, the initial workshop was converted to an online format, but otherwise proceeded as usual. By the end of the program, participants were able to create a novel product idea, describe how they used the key design considerations in the design process, and state the features, benefits and impacts of their products through production of a promotional presentation. Product ideas varied widely and included a surgical stapler for colorectal applications, a system for prenatal detection of congenital heart disease, a wearable device for stroke detection, a self-adjusting prosthesis, and a Parkinson's Anti-Tremor Handle (PATH)

 

Students were surveyed before and after the program. A majority of students agreed or highly agreed that the MINDS program had improved their perceived skills in understanding the design considerations addressed in the program and applying them to any project, assessing product requirements, explaining key features of a project, communicating technical matters to others, collaborating remotely, understanding the process of developing a product, and working in a team. Many students also reported that MINDS impacted their career goals. The results of the 2021-2022 program, and feedback from students and mentors, will be used to improve the program for future cohorts.

 

Some quotes from 2021-2022 students were as follows:

 

"MINDS has helped me gain and nurture analytical, research, teamwork, leadership, and organizational skills."

 "I enjoyed getting connected with students and mentors across the nation. It definitely allowed for a unique networking opportunity [...] with others from different backgrounds who all have the same goal in mind to improve healthcare."

"MINDS helped me understand how much forethought and prior research goes into designing a product before the actual build."

"The MINDS program has definitely showed me how best to communicate technical information and engineering knowledge within a group."

"The iterative design process was emphasised and the constant review of work was invaluable"

"This program had us walk through the engineering design process which will be crucial to senior design next school year. I have come out of this with a much stronger understanding of how this process works, and can tell, in speaking with seniors and other engineering students, that I am already ahead of the game because of this program."

  

In summary, we achieved our aims of teaching students how to integrate market needs, regulatory considerations, and intellectual property strategy into the design process. In doing this, we also increased their awareness of how biomedical devices and technologies can benefit society.
